revised_title: Skin Friction Measurement in Supersonic Turbulent Boundary Layer
tldr: The authors measured skin friction in a turbulent boundary layer at a Mach number of 2.5, including the effect of a shock wave. They used a surface-tube technique and found that the surface tube is a reliable method for measuring skin friction even in supersonic conditions. The results also show that disturbances due to a shock wave only propagate upstream a few multiples of the boundary layer thicknesses, even when strong enough to cause local separation.
